''[[Atlas Shrugged]]'' | signature=Sign Ayn Rand.png }} '''Ayn Rand''' ({{IPA-en|ˈaɪn ˈrænd|pron}};{{cite web |url=http://www.aynrand.org/site/PageServer?pagename=about_ayn_rand_faq_index2#ar_q3 |title=Frequently Asked Questions About Ayn Rand: How do you pronounce 'Ayn'? |publisher=[[Ayn Rand Institute]] |accessdate=February 6, 2010}} born '''Alisa Zinov'yevna Rosenbaum'''; {{OldStyleDate|February 2|1905|January 20}} – March 6, 1982), was a [[Russian-American]] novelist, philosopher,The following sources identify Rand as a philosopher: * {{harvnb|Long|2010}}. "Ayn Rand (1905–1982) was a philosopher and a novelist who outlined a comprehensive philosophy, including an epistemology and a theory of art, in her novels and essays." * {{harvnb|Saxon|1982|p=36}}. "Ayn Rand, the writer and philosopher of objectivism who espoused 'rational selfishness' and capitalism unbound, died yesterday morning at her home on East 34th Street." * "Preface" in {{harvnb|Den Uyl|Rasmussen|1986|p=x}}. "... this book is devoted to an assessment of Ayn Rand the philosopher. All the contributors to this volume agree that she is a philosopher and not a mere popularizer. Moreover, all agree that many of her insights on philosophy and her own philosophic ideas deserve critical attention by professional philosophers, whatever the final merit of those inquiries and theories. It is appropriate, therefore, that all our contributors are themselves professional philosophers." * {{harvnb|Sciabarra|1995|p=1}}. "Ayn Rand is one of the most widely read philosophers of the twentieth century." * {{harvnb|Kukathas|1998|p=55}}. "Ayn Rand was a Russian-born novelist and philosopher who exerted considerable influence in the conservative and libertarian intellectual movements in the post-war USA." playwright, and screenwriter. She is known for her [[Bibliography of Ayn Rand|two best-selling novels]] and for developing a philosophical system she called [[Objectivism (Ayn Rand)|Objectivism]]. Born and educated in Russia, Rand immigrated to the United States in 1926. She worked as a screenwriter in Hollywood and had a play produced on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] in 1935–1936. She first achieved fame in 1943 with her novel ''[[The Fountainhead]]'', which in 1957 was followed by her best-known work, the philosophical novel ''[[Atlas Shrugged]]''. Rand's political views, reflected in both her fiction and her theoretical work, emphasize [[individual rights]] (including property rights) and [[laissez-faire]] capitalism, enforced by a constitutionally [[limited government]]. She was a fierce opponent of all forms of [[collectivism]] and [[statism]],{{cite journal |last=Rand |first=Ayn |title=The Only Path to Tomorrow |journal=[[Reader's Digest]] |month=January |year=1944 |volume=44 |issue=261 |pages=88–90 |url=http://fare.tunes.org/liberty/library/toptt.html}} Reprinted in{{cite book |first=Ayn |last=Rand |title=The Ayn Rand Column |publisher=Second Renaissance Books |location=Oceanside, California |year=1991 |isbn=1-56114-099-6 |oclc=26061978 |editor-first=Peter |editor-last=Schwartz |editor-link=Peter Schwartz (writer) |pages=105–108}}"Racism" in {{harvnb|Rand|1964|p=149}} including [[fascism]], [[communism]], [[socialism]], and the [[welfare state]],{{cite book |title=[[Capitalism: The Unknown Ideal]] |chapter="Extremism," or The Art of Smearing |page=180 |isbn=0-451-14795-2 |year=1967 |location=New York |publisher=Signet |oclc=24916193 |last=Rand |first=Ayn}} and promoted [[ethical egoism]] while rejecting the [[Altruism (ethics)|ethic of altruism]]."Introduction" in {{harvnb|Rand|1964|p=ix}} She considered [[reason]] to be the only means of acquiring [[knowledge]] and the most important aspect of her philosophy,{{cite book |title=[[Return of the Primitive: The Anti-Industrial Revolution]] |chapter=The Left: Old and New |page=62 |isbn=0-452-01184-1 |oclc=39281836 |year=1999 |location=New York |publisher=Meridian |last=Rand |first=Ayn |others=Edited by Peter Schwartz}} stating, "I am not ''primarily'' an advocate of capitalism, but of egoism; and I am not ''primarily'' an advocate of egoism, but of reason. If one recognizes the supremacy of reason and applies it consistently, all the rest follows."{{cite journal |last=Rand |first=Ayn |title=Brief Summary |journal=[[The Objectivist]] |month=September |year=1971 |volume=10 |issue=9 |page=1}} ==Life and work== ===Early life=== Rand was born Alisa Zinov'yevna Rosenbaum ({{lang-ru|Алиса Зиновьевна Розенбаум}}) in 1905, to a [[bourgeois]] family living in [[Saint Petersburg]]. She was the eldest of the three daughters (Alisa, Natasha, and Nora) of Zinovy Zakharovich Rosenbaum and Anna Borisovna Rosenbaum, largely non-observant [[Jews]]. Her father was educated as a [[chemist]] and became a successful pharmacist, eventually owning his own pharmacy and the building in which it was located.{{harvnb|Heller|2009|pp=3–5}}; {{harvnb|Britting|2004|pp=2–3}} His success allowed the family to employ a cook, maid, nurse, and [[governess]].{{harvnb|Heller|2009|p=5}} Growing up, she was praised by adults for her intelligence, but her intensity and social awkwardness meant she rarely had friends her own age. On one occasion, when a school assignment called for her to write about the joys of childhood, she instead wrote what she later recalled as "a scathing denunciation" of childhood as inferior to the intellectual capacity of adults.{{harvnb|Heller|2009|pp=11–27}} Rand was twelve at the time of the [[Russian revolution of 1917]]. Opposed to the [[Nicholas II of Russia|Tsar]], Rand's sympathies were with [[Alexander Kerensky]]. Rand's family life was disrupted by the rise of the [[Bolshevik]] party under [[Vladimir Lenin]]. Her father's pharmacy was confiscated by the Bolsheviks, and the family fled to the [[Crimea]], which was initially under the control of the [[White movement|White Army]] during the [[Russian Civil War]]. She later recalled that while in high school she determined that she was an [[atheist]] and that she valued reason and intellect. After graduating from high school in the Crimea she briefly held a job teaching [[Red Army]] soldiers to read. She found she enjoyed that work very much, the illiterate soldiers being eager to learn and respectful of her. At sixteen, Rand returned with her family to Saint Petersburg.{{harvnb|Branden|1986|pp=35–39}}{{harvnb|Britting|2004|pp=14–20}} [[Image:Twelvecollegia.jpg|thumb|left|alt=A black-and-white engraving shows a large building along the bank of a river, with numerous people and carriages nearby|Rand completed a three-year program in the department of social pedagogy at [[Saint Petersburg State University|Petrograd State University]].]] Following the [[Russian Revolution]], universities were opened to women and Jews, allowing Rand to be in the first group of women to enroll at [[Saint Petersburg State University|Petrograd State University]],{{harvnb|Burns|2009|p=15}} where she studied in the department of [[social pedagogy]], majoring in history.{{cite journal |last=Sciabarra |first=Chris Matthew |url=http://www.nyu.edu/projects/sciabarra/essays/randt2.htm |title=The Rand Transcript" |journal=[[The Journal of Ayn Rand Studies]] |volume=1 |issue=1 |year=1999 |month=Fall |pages=1–26}} At the university she was introduced to the writings of [[Aristotle]] and [[Plato]], who would form two of the greatest influences and counter-influences respectively on her thought.{{harvnb|Peikoff|1991|pp=451–460}} A third figure whose philosophical works she studied heavily was [[Friedrich Nietzsche]].{{harvnb|Britting|2004|pp=17–18, 22–24}} Her formal study of philosophy amounted to only a few courses, and outside of these three philosophers, her study of key figures was limited to excerpts and summaries.{{harvnb|Sciabarra|1995|p=12}} Of the writers she read at this time, [[Victor Hugo]], [[Edmond Rostand]], [[Friedrich Schiller]], and [[Fyodor Dostoevsky]] became her perennial favorites.{{harvnb|Britting|2004|pp=17, 22}} Along with other non-Communist students, Rand was purged from the university shortly before graduating. However, after complaints from a group of visiting foreign scientists, some of the purged students were allowed to complete their work and graduate,{{harvnb|Heller|2009|p=47}}; {{harvnb|Britting|2004|p=24}} which Rand did in October 1924. She subsequently studied for a year at the State [[Technicum]] for Screen Arts in Leningrad.{{cite book |title=Russian Writings on Hollywood |chapter=Introduction |year=1999 |editor-first=Michael S. |editor-last=Berliner |others=Ayn Rand, trans. by Dina Garmong |location=Los Angeles |publisher=Ayn Rand Institute Press |isbn=0-9625336-3-7 |oclc=40851490 |page=10}} In the fall of 1925, she was granted a [[Visa (document)|visa]] to visit American relatives. As her train pulled away she called out to her family, "By the time I return, I'll be famous!" Leaving Russia on January 17, 1926, Rand arrived in the United States on February 19, entering by ship through [[New York City]].{{harvnb|Heller|2009|pp=50–53}}; {{harvnb|Britting|2004|p=30}} She was so impressed with the skyline of [[Manhattan]] upon her arrival that she cried what she later called "tears of splendor".{{harvnb|Heller|2009|p=53}} Intent on staying in the United States to become a screenwriter, she lived for a few months with relatives in [[Chicago]], one of whom owned a movie theater and allowed her to watch hundreds of films for free, then she set out for [[Hollywood, California]].{{harvnb|Heller|2009|pp=57–60}} While still in Russia she had decided her professional surname for writing would be ''Rand'',{{harvnb|Britting|2004|p=33}} possibly as a [[Cyrillic]] [[contraction (grammar)|contraction]] of her birth surname,{{cite web |url=http://www.aynrand.org/site/PageServer?pagename=about_ayn_rand_faq_index2#ar_q3b |title=Frequently Asked Questions About Ayn Rand: What is the origin of “Rand”? |publisher=Ayn Rand Institute |accessdate=April 2, 2010}} and she adopted the first name ''Ayn'', either from a Finnish name or from the Hebrew word {{lang|he| עין}} (''ayin'', meaning "eye").Rand said the origin of ''Ayn'' was Finnish {{harv|Rand|1995|p=40}}, but some biographical sources question this, suggesting it may come from a Hebrew nickname. {{harvnb|Heller|2009|pp=55–57}} provides a detailed discussion. Initially, she struggled in Hollywood and took odd jobs to pay her basic living expenses. A chance meeting with famed director [[Cecil B. DeMille]] led to a job as an [[extra (drama)|extra]] in his film, ''[[The King of Kings]]'', and to subsequent work as a junior screenwriter.{{harvnb|Britting|2004|pp=34–36}} While working on ''The King of Kings'', she intentionally bumped into an aspiring young actor, Frank O'Connor, who caught her eye. The two were married on April 15, 1929. Rand became an [[Naturalization|American citizen]] in 1931. Taking various jobs during the 1930s to support her writing, Rand worked for a time as the head of the costume department at [[RKO]] Studios.{{harvnb|Britting|2004|pp=35–40}}; {{harvnb|Paxton|1998|pp=74, 81, 84}} She made attempts to bring her parents and sisters to the United States, but they were unable to get permission to emigrate.{{harvnb|Heller|2009|pp=96–98}}; {{harvnb|Britting|2004|pp=43–44, 52}} [[Image:Pola Negri by Ayn Rand cover.jpg|thumb|right|alt=A brown book cover with black-and-white drawings and text in Russian. The drawing on the left is a portrait of a woman with dark hair; the drawing on the right is of skyscrapers.|Cover of Rand's first book, a 2,500-word monograph on the Polish ''femme fatale'' [[Pola Negri]] published in 1925.{{cite journal |journal=Archives Annual |last=Berliner |first=Michael S. |volume=2 |year=1999 |title=Ayn Rand's First Published Work Found |publisher=Ayn Rand Institute |url=http://www.aynrand.org/site/DocServer/volume2.pdf?docID=122 |format=PDF |page=8}} Originally published in the Institute's ''Impact'' newsletter, March 1996.]] ===Early fiction=== {{See also|Night of January 16th|We the Living|Anthem (novella)}} In the late 1920s, Rand worked on a number of writing projects, including movie scenarios, short stories, and a novel called ''The Little Street''.{{harvnb|Rand|1997|pp=3, 20}} The hero of ''The Little Street'' was described as having "the true, innate psychology of a Superman" and was to be based on an idealized portrait of child killer [[William Edward Hickman]].{{harvnb|Rand|1997|pp=27}} Rand scholars have interpreted her notes for this book as evidence of her early admiration of the ideas of [[Friedrich Nietzsche]].{{harvnb|Rand|1997|pp=21}}; {{harvnb|Burns|2009|pp=24–25}};{{cite journal |title=A Renaissance in Rand Scholarship |last=Sciabarra |first=Chris Matthew |authorlink=Chris Matthew Sciabarra |journal=Reason Papers |volume=23 |month=Fall |year=1998 |pages=132–159 |url=http://www.nyu.edu/projects/sciabarra/essays/rprev.htm}};{{cite journal |title=Ronald E. Merrill and the Discovery of Ayn Rand's Nietzschean Period |last=Reed |first=Adam |journal=[[The Journal of Ayn Rand Studies]] |volume=10 |month=Spring |year=2009 |pages=325–326 |issue=2}} However, the novel was never completed and none of the other projects were produced or published during Rand's lifetime. Rand's first literary success came with the sale of her screenplay ''[[Red Pawn]]'' to [[Universal Studios]] in 1932. [[Josef Von Sternberg]] considered it for [[Marlene Dietrich]], but anti-Soviet themes were unpopular at the time, and the project came to nothing.{{harvnb|Britting|2004|pp=40, 42}} This was followed by the [[courtroom drama]] ''[[Night of January 16th]]'', first produced in Hollywood in 1934, and then successfully reopened on [[Broadway theater|Broadway]] in 1935. Each night the "jury" was selected from members of the audience, and one of the two different endings, depending on the jury's "verdict," would then be performed.{{harvnb|Rand|1971|pp=3–11}} In 1941, [[Paramount Pictures]] produced a movie version of the play. Rand did not participate in the production and was highly critical of the result.{{cite book |title=The Fountainheads: Wright, Rand, the FBI and Hollywood |last=Johnson |first=Donald Leslie |location=Jefferson, North Carolina |publisher=McFarland & Company |year=2005 |isbn=0-7864-1958-X |oclc=56617298 |pages=55–56}} ''cf''. {{harvnb|Rand|1971|pp=13–14}} Her first novel, the semi-autobiographical ''[[We the Living]]'', was published in 1936 by [[Macmillan Publishers|Macmillan]]. Set in Communist Russia, it focused on the struggle between the individual and the state. In the foreword to the novel, Rand stated that ''We the Living'' "is as near to an autobiography as I will ever write. It is not an autobiography in the literal, but only in the intellectual sense. The plot is invented, the background is not..."{{cite book |last=Rand |first=Ayn |chapter=Foreword |title=We The Living |location=New York |publisher=Dutton |page=xviii |isbn=0-525-94054-5 |oclc=32780458 |edition=60th Anniversary |year=1995 |origyear=1936}} Without Rand's knowledge or permission, ''We the Living'' was made into a pair of Italian films, ''Noi vivi'' and ''Addio, Kira'', in 1942. Rediscovered in the 1960s, these films were re-edited into a new version which was approved by Rand and re-released as ''We the Living'' in 1986.{{harvnb|Paxton|1998|p=104}} Her novella ''[[Anthem (novella)|Anthem]]'' was published in England in 1938 and in America seven years later. It presents a vision of a [[dystopian]] future world in which collectivism has triumphed to such an extent that even [[Personal pronoun|the word "I"]] has vanished from the language and from humanity's memory. ===''The Fountainhead'' and political activism=== {{See also|The Fountainhead|The Fountainhead (film)}} {{Quote box | quote = "The great creators - the thinkers, the artists, the scientists, the inventors - stood alone against the men of their time. Every great new thought was opposed. Every great new invention was denounced. The first motor was considered foolish. The airplane was considered impossible. The power loom was considered vicious. Anesthesia was considered sinful. But the men of unborrowed vision went ahead. They fought, they suffered and they paid." | source = [[Howard Roark]], ''[[The Fountainhead]]'' ''[[The Fountainhead]]'', by Ayn Rand, Signet, ISBN 0451191153, pp 710 | width = 28% | align = right }} During the 1940s, Rand became involved in political activism. Both she and her husband worked full time in volunteer positions for the 1940 Presidential campaign of Republican [[Wendell Willkie]]. This work led to Rand's first public speaking experiences, including fielding the sometimes hostile questions from New York City audiences who had just viewed pro-Willkie newsreels, an experience she greatly enjoyed.{{harvnb|Britting|2004|p=57}} This activity also brought her into contact with other intellectuals sympathetic to free-market capitalism. She became friends with journalist [[Henry Hazlitt]] and his wife, and Hazlitt introduced her to the [[Austrian School]] economist [[Ludwig von Mises]]. Both men expressed an admiration for Rand, and despite her philosophical differences with them, Rand strongly endorsed the writings of both men throughout her career.{{harvnb|Branden|1986|pp=188–189}} Von Mises in particular would later pen an admiring 1958 letter to Rand, remarking "You have the courage to tell the masses what no politician told them: You are inferior, and all the improvements in your condition which you simply take for granted, you owe to the effort of men who are better than you."{{harvnb|Burns|2009|pp= 177}} She also developed a friendship with [[libertarianism|libertarian]] writer [[Isabel Paterson]]. Rand questioned the well-informed Paterson about American history and politics long into the night during their numerous meetings, and gave Paterson ideas for her only nonfiction book, ''[[The God of the Machine]]''.{{harvnb|Burns|2009|pp=75–78}} Rand's first major success as a writer came with ''[[The Fountainhead]]'' in 1943, a romantic and philosophical novel that she wrote over a period of seven years.{{harvnb|Britting|2004|pp=61–78}} The novel centers on an uncompromising young [[architect]] named [[Howard Roark]], and his struggle against what Rand described as "second-handers"—those who attempt to live through others, placing others above self. It was rejected by twelve publishers before finally being accepted by the [[Bobbs-Merrill Company]] on the insistence of editor Archibald Ogden, who threatened to quit if his employer did not publish it.{{harvnb|Britting|2004|pp=58–61}} While completing the novel, Rand began taking the prescription [[amphetamine]] [[Benzedrine]] to fight fatigue.{{harvnb|Burns|2009|p=85}} Her use of the drug enabled her to work long hours to meet her deadline for delivering the finished novel to Bobbs-Merrill, but when the book was done she was so exhausted that her doctor ordered two weeks rest.{{harvnb|Burns|2009|p=89}} Her continued use of it for several decades also may have contributed to volatile mood swings observed by her associates in later years.{{harvnb|Burns|2009|p=178}}; {{harvnb|Heller|pp=304–305}} ''The Fountainhead'' eventually became a worldwide success, bringing Rand fame and financial security.According to the [[Ayn Rand Institute]], by April 2008 the novel had sold over 6.5 million copies.{{cite web |title=Sales of Ayn Rand Books Reach 25 million Copies |url=http://www.aynrand.org/site/News2?page=NewsArticle&id=17345 |date=April 7, 2008 |accessdate=July 31, 2009 |publisher=Ayn Rand Institute}} In 1943, Rand sold the rights for a [[The Fountainhead (film)|film version]] to [[Warner Brothers]], and she returned to Hollywood to write the screenplay. Finishing her work on that screenplay, she was hired by producer [[Hal Wallis]] as a screenwriter and script-doctor, and her work for Wallis included the Oscar-nominated [[Love Letters (1945 film)|''Love Letters'']] and ''[[You Came Along]]'', along with research for a screenplay based on the development of the [[Nuclear Weapon|atomic bomb]].{{harvnb|Britting|2004|pp=68–80}}; {{harvnb|Branden|1986|pp=183–198}} This role gave Rand time to work on other projects, including the publication of her first work of nonfiction, an essay titled "The Only Path to Tomorrow", in the January 1944 edition of ''[[Reader's Digest]]'' magazine. Rand also outlined and took extensive notes for a nonfiction treatment of her philosophy, although the planned book was never completed.{{harvnb|Rand|1997|pp=243–310}} While working in Hollywood, Rand extended her involvement with free-market and anti-Communist activism. She and her husband purchased a [[Von Sternberg House|house]] designed by modernist [[Richard Neutra]] and an adjoining ranch. There, Rand entertained figures such as Hazlitt, [[Morrie Ryskind]], [[Albert Mannheimer]] and [[Leonard Read]]. A visit by Paterson to meet with Rand's California associates led to a final falling out between the two when Paterson made comments that Rand saw as rude to valued political allies, and also revealed that she had refused to do a review of ''The Fountainhead'' in the newspaper for which she worked.{{harvnb|Burns|2009|pp=130–131}}; {{harvnb|Heller|2009|pp=214–215}}; {{harvnb|Rand|1997|p=131}} Despite their break, Rand continued to promote Paterson's ''The God of the Machine''.{{harvnb|Heller|2009|p=217}} While in California, Rand also became involved with the [[Motion Picture Alliance for the Preservation of American Ideals]], a Hollywood anti-Communist group, and wrote articles on the group's behalf.{{harvnb|Burns|2009|pp=100, 123}} {{Wikisource|Ayn Rand's testimony before the House of Representatives Committee on Un-American Activities}} In 1947, during the [[Second Red Scare]], Rand testified as a "friendly witness" before the United States [[House Un-American Activities Committee]]. Her testimony described the disparity between her personal experiences in the [[Soviet Union]] and the portrayal of it in the 1944 film ''[[Song of Russia]]''.{{harvnb|Mayhew|2005|pp=91–93}} Rand argued that the film grossly misrepresented conditions in the Soviet Union, portraying life there as being much better and happier than it actually was."[http://www.capmag.com/article.asp?ID=12 Ayn Rand's HUAC Testimony]" in {{harvnb|Mayhew|2005|pp=188–189}} When asked about her feelings on the effectiveness of the investigations after the hearings, Rand described the process as "futile".{{harvnb|Mayhew|2005|p=83}} After several delays, the movie version of ''The Fountainhead'' was released in 1949. Although it used Rand's screenplay with minimal alterations, she "disliked the movie from beginning to end," complaining about its editing, acting and other elements.{{harvnb|Britting|2004|p=71}} ===''Atlas Shrugged'' and Objectivism=== {{See also|Atlas Shrugged|Objectivist movement}} {{Quote box | quote = "The man at the top of the intellectual pyramid contributes the most to all those below him, but gets nothing except his material payment, receiving no intellectual bonus from others to add to the value of his time. The man at the bottom who, left to himself, would starve in his hopeless ineptitude, contributes nothing to those above him, but receives the bonus of all their brains. Such is the nature of the competition between the strong and the weak of the intellect. Such is the pattern of exploitation for which you have damned the strong." | source = [[John Galt]], ''[[Atlas Shrugged]]'' "About the Author" in {{harvnb|Rand|1992|pp=1065}} | width = 32% | align = right }} After the publication of ''The Fountainhead'', Rand received numerous letters from readers, some of whom it had profoundly influenced. In 1951 Rand moved from Los Angeles to New York City, where she gathered a group of these admirers around her. This group (jokingly designated "The Collective") included future Federal Reserve chairman [[Alan Greenspan]], a young psychology student named Nathan Blumenthal (later [[Nathaniel Branden]]) and his wife [[Barbara Branden|Barbara]], and Barbara's cousin [[Leonard Peikoff]]. At first the group was an informal gathering of friends who met with Rand on weekends at her apartment to discuss philosophy. Later she began allowing them to read the drafts of her new novel, ''Atlas Shrugged'', as the manuscript pages were written. In 1954 Rand's close relationship with the much younger [[Nathaniel Branden]] turned into a romantic affair, with the consent of their spouses.{{harvnb|Branden|1986|pp=256–264, 331–343}} ''Atlas Shrugged'', published in 1957, was Rand's ''magnum opus''.{{harvnb|Rand|1997|p=704}} Rand described the theme of the novel as "the role of the mind in man's existence—and, as a corollary, the demonstration of a new moral philosophy: the morality of rational self-interest."{{cite book |last=Rand |first=Ayn |title=For the New Intellectual |location=New York |publisher=Signet |year=1963 |origyear=1961 |isbn=0-451-16308-7 |oclc=36698277 |page=88}} It advocates the core tenets of Rand's philosophy of [[Objectivism (Ayn Rand)|Objectivism]] and expresses her concept of human achievement. The plot involves a [[dystopia]]n United States in which the most creative industrialists, scientists and artists go on [[strike action|strike]] and retreat to a mountainous hideaway where they build an independent free economy. The novel's hero and leader of the strike, [[John Galt]], describes the strike as "stopping the motor of the world" by withdrawing the minds of the individuals most contributing to the nation's wealth and achievement. With this fictional strike, Rand intended to illustrate that without the efforts of the rational and productive, the economy would collapse and society would fall apart. The novel includes elements of [[mystery (fiction)|mystery]] and [[science fiction]],{{harvnb|Gladstein|1999|p=42}} and it contains Rand's most extensive statement of Objectivism in any of her works of fiction, a lengthy monologue delivered by Galt. ''Atlas Shrugged'' became an international bestseller, and in an interview with [[Mike Wallace]] Rand declared herself "the most creative thinker alive."{{harvnb|Burns|2009|p=2}} Rand's last work of fiction, it marked a turning point in her life, ending her career as novelist and beginning her role as a popular philosopher.{{cite book |title=Ayn Rand's Atlas Shrugged: A Philosophical and Literary Companion |editor-last=Younkins |editor-first=Edward W. |location=Burlington, Vermont |publisher=Ashgate Publishing |year=2007 |isbn=978-0-7546-5533-6 |oclc=69792104 |chapter=Introduction |page=1}} After the book received many negative reviews, however, Rand fell into a severe [[Depression (mood)|depression]] that may have been aggravated by her use of prescription amphetamines.{{harvnb|Burns|2009|p=178}}; {{harvnb|Heller|2009|pp=303–306}} In 1958 [[Nathaniel Branden]] established Nathaniel Branden Lectures, later incorporated as the [[Nathaniel Branden Institute]] (NBI), to promote Rand's philosophy. Collective members gave lectures for NBI and wrote articles for [[Objectivist periodicals]] that she edited. Rand later published some of these articles in book form. Critics, including some former NBI students and Branden himself, have described the culture of NBI as one of intellectual conformity and excessive reverence for Rand, with some describing NBI or the entire [[Objectivist movement]] as a [[cult]] or religion.{{harvnb|Gladstein|2009|pp=105–106}}; {{harvnb|Burns|2009|pp=232–233}} Rand expressed opinions on a wide range of topics, including literature, music, sexuality, even facial hair, and some of her followers mimicked all her preferences, wearing clothes to match characters from her novels and buying furniture like hers.{{harvnb|Burns|2009|pp=236–237}} Rand was unimpressed with many of the NBI students{{harvnb|Heller|2009|p=303}} and held them to strict standards, often reacting coldly or angrily to those who disagreed with her.{{harvnb|Doherty|2007|pp=237–238}}; {{harvnb|Heller|2009|p=329}}; {{harvnb|Burns|2009|p=235}} However, some former NBI students believe the extent of these behaviors has been exaggerated, with the problem being concentrated among Rand's closest followers in New York.{{harvnb|Doherty|2007|p=235}}; {{harvnb|Burns|2009|p=235}} ===Later years=== Throughout the 1960s and 1970s Rand developed and promoted her Objectivist philosophy through her nonfiction works and by giving talks, for example at [[Yale University]], [[Princeton University]], [[Columbia University]],{{harvnb|Branden|1986|pp=315–316}} [[Harvard University]] and [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]].{{harvnb|Gladstein|1999|p=14}} She received an honorary doctorate from [[Lewis & Clark College]] in 1963.{{harvnb|Branden|1986|p=318}} She also began delivering annual lectures at the [[Ford Hall Forum]], responding afterwards in her famously spirited form to questions from the audience.{{harvnb|Gladstein|1999|p=16}} Leading up to the [[United States presidential election, 1964|U.S. Presidential election of 1964]], Rand became a fan of [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] candidate [[Barry Goldwater]], telling him "I regard you as the only hope of the anti-collectivist side on today's political scene, and I have defended your position at every opportunity."[http://reason.com/archives/2007/10/15/rand-and-the-right/print Rand and the Right: Reflections on the 50th anniversary of Atlas Shrugged] by Brian Doherty, ''[[Reason magazine]]'', October 15, 2007 Like Goldwater, Rand opposed the [[1964 Civil Rights Act]], which at the time was seen as a "litmus test of liberal acceptability."{{harvnb|Burns|2009|pp=205}} In 1964 Nathaniel Branden began an affair with the young actress Patrecia Scott, whom he later married. Nathaniel and Barbara Branden kept the affair hidden from Rand. When she learned of it in 1968, though her romantic relationship with Branden had already ended,{{harvnb|Britting|2004|p=101}} Rand terminated her relationship with both Brandens, which led to the closure of NBI.{{harvnb|Branden|1986|pp=344–358}} Rand published an article in ''The Objectivist'' repudiating Nathaniel Branden for dishonesty and other "irrational behavior in his private life."{{cite journal |last=Rand |first=Ayn |title=To Whom It May Concern |journal=[[The Objectivist]] |volume=7 |issue=5 |pages=1–8 |location=New York |year=1968 |month=May}} For his part, Branden later responded by apologizing in ''[[Reason magazine]]'' to "every student of Objectivism" for "perpetuating the Ayn Rand mystique" and for "contributing to that dreadful atmosphere of intellectual repressiveness that pervades the Objectivist movement."''[[Reason magazine]]'', October 1971 issue, pp. 12-16 [http://libertyunbound.com/article.php?id=408 Who Is Nathaniel Branden?] a review by [[R.W. Bradford]], ''[[Liberty (1987)|Liberty]]'' magazine, July 1989, Vol. 2, No. 6 During the 1970's, Rand was prompted by her fans to take part in a number of Q&A sessions. However, a number of her controversial stances during these events particularly outraged her libertarian supporters.{{harvnb|Burns|2009|pp=266}} One example was a 1971 Q&A session, where Rand denounced [[homosexuality]] as involving "psychological flaws", while also being "immoral" and "disgusting."''Feminist Interpretations of Ayn Rand'', by [[Mimi Reisel Gladstein]] & [[Chris Matthew Sciabarra]], Penn State Press, 1999, ISBN 0271018313, pp 358[http://www.aynrand.org/site/PageServer?pagename=reg_ar_moratorium "The Moratorium on Brains", a Q & A with Ayn Rand in 1971] - audio provided by the [[Ayn Rand Institute]] Other examples included her at [[West Point Military Academy|West Point]] in 1974 attacking [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]] as "savages" who lived like "cavemen or animals", while arguing that [[European colonization of the Americas|European colonists]] had a right to seize their land because such nomadic tribes did not recognize individual rights;Ayn Rand Answers: The Best of Her Q & A, edited by Robert Mayhew, 2005, NAL Trade, ISBN 0451216652, pg 102-104 and her argument that "primitive" [[Palestinians]] had no rights in opposing [[Israel]], "the sole outpost of civilization" in the [[Middle East]].[http://www.aynrand.org/site/PageServer?pagename=media_america_at_war_israeli_arab_conflict Ayn Rand Ford Hall Forum Lecture], 1974, text published on the website of [[The Ayn Rand Institute]] When asked again about the latter topic during a May 1979 episode of the ''[[The Phil Donahue Show]]'', Rand reprised her support for Israel as "the advanced, technological, civilized country amidst a group of almost totally primitive savages." [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2uHSv1asFvU May 16, 1979 Video Clip of ''The Phil Donahue Show'', Featuring Ayn Rand] ===Death=== [[File:Ayn Rand and Frank O'Connor Monument 2010.JPG|thumb|left|Grave marker for Rand and her husband|alt=A twin gravestone bearing the name "Frank O'Connor" on the left, and "Ayn Rand O'Connor" on the right]] A heavy smoker, Rand underwent surgery for [[lung cancer]] in 1974. Several more of her closest associates parted company with her,{{harvnb|Branden|1986|pp=386–389}} and during the late 1970s her activities within the [[Objectivist movement]] declined, especially after the death of her husband on November 9, 1979.{{harvnb|Branden|1986|pp=392–395}} One of her final projects was work on a television adaptation of ''Atlas Shrugged''. She had also planned to write another novel, but did not get far in her notes.{{harvnb|Rand|1997|p=697}} Rand died of [[heart failure]] on March 6, 1982 at her home in New York City,{{harvnb|Saxon|1982|p=36}} and was interred in the [[Kensico Cemetery]], [[Valhalla, New York]]. Rand's funeral was attended by some of her prominent followers, including Alan Greenspan. A six-foot floral arrangement in the shape of a dollar sign was placed near her casket.{{harvnb|Branden|1986|p=403}} In her will, Rand named [[Leonard Peikoff]] the heir to her estate. With her endorsement of his 1976 lecture series, she had recognized his work as being the best exposition of her philosophy.{{harvnb|Peikoff|1991|pp=xiii–xv}} ==Philosophy== {{Objectivist movement}}{{Main|Objectivism (Ayn Rand)}} Rand developed an integrated philosophical system called "Objectivism." Its essence is "the concept of man as a heroic being, with his own happiness as the moral purpose of his life, with productive achievement as his noblest activity, and reason as his only absolute.""About the Author" in {{harvnb|Rand|1992|pp=1170–1171}} Objectivism has been described pejoratively as "[[pseudophilosophy]]".{{cite news |first=Leslie |last=Clark |title=The philosophical art of looking out number one |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/the-philosophical-art-of-looking-out-number-one-1.835066 |work=[[The Herald (Glasgow)|The Herald]] |date=February 17, 2007 |accessdate=April 2, 2010}} As an [[atheist]] who rejected [[faith]] as antithetical to reason, Rand embraced [[philosophical realism]] and opposed all forms of [[mysticism]] or [[supernaturalism]], including organized religion.Den Uyl, Douglas J. & Rasmussen, Douglas B. "Ayn Rand's Realism" in {{harvnb|Den Uyl|Rasmussen|1986|pp=3–20}} Of [[Christianity]] in particular, Rand wrote in her journals that it was "the best kindergarten of communism possible."{{harvnb|Burns|2009|pp=43}} Rand also argued for [[rational egoism]] (rational self-interest), as the only proper guiding moral principle. The individual "must exist for his own sake," she wrote in 1962, "neither sacrificing himself to others nor sacrificing others to himself."{{cite book |title=[[The Voice of Reason]] |first=Ayn |last=Rand |others=Edited by Leonard Peikoff |location=New York |publisher=New American Library |year=1989 |isbn=0-453-00634-5 |oclc=18048955 |chapter=Introducing Objectivism |page=3}} This article originally appeared in the ''Los Angeles Times'' on June 17, 1962. Rand held that the only moral social system is ''laissez-faire'' capitalism. Her political views were strongly [[individualism|individualist]] and hence [[anti-statist]] and [[anti-Communist]]. Rand was strongly opposed to many [[Liberalism in the United States|liberal]] and [[Conservatism in the United States|conservative]] politicians of her time, including prominent anti-Communists.{{cite news |last=Toffler |first=Alvin |authorlink=Alvin Toffler |title=Playboy Interview: Ayn Rand |work=[[Playboy]] |month=March |year=1964 |volume=11 |issue=3 |url=http://www.playboy.com/articles/ayn-rand-playboy-interview/index.html |pages=35–43}}{{cite news |authorlink=Maureen Dowd |first=Maureen |last=Dowd |title=Where 'Atlas Shrugged' Is Still Read - Forthrightly |url=http://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/13/weekinreview/where-atlas-shrugged-is-still-read-forthrightly.html?pagewanted=all |work=The New York Times |date=September 13, 1987 |page=E5}} She rejected the [[libertarian movement]],{{harvnb|Burns|2009|p=258}}; {{harvnb|Rand|2005|p=73}} although [[Jim Powell (historian)|Jim Powell]], a senior fellow at the [[Cato Institute]], considers Rand one of the three most important women (along with [[Rose Wilder Lane]] and [[Isabel Paterson]]) of modern American [[libertarianism]].{{cite journal |last=Powell |first=Jim |authorlink=Jim Powell (historian) |title=Rose Wilder Lane, Isabel Paterson, and Ayn Rand: Three Women Who Inspired the Modern Libertarian Movement |url=http://www.thefreemanonline.org/featured/rose-wilder-lane-isabel-paterson-and-ayn-rand-three-women-who-inspired-the-modern-libertarian-movement/ |journal=[[The Freeman|The Freeman: Ideas on Liberty]] |month=May |year=1996 |volume=46 |issue=5 |page=322}} Rand rejected [[anarcho-capitalism]] as "a contradiction in terms", a point on which she has been criticized by self-avowed anarchist Objectivists such as [[Roy Childs]].{{cite book |editor1-last=Machan |editor1-first=Tibor |editor1-link=Tibor R. Machan |editor2-first=Roderick |editor2-last=Long |editor2-link=Roderick Long |title=Anarchism/Minarchism |publisher=Ashgate |location=Aldershot |year=2008 |isbn=0-7546-6066-4 |oclc=85766066 |first=William R. |last=Thomas |chapter=Objectivism against Anarchy |pages=39–57 |lastauthoramp=y |chapterurl=http://www.atlassociety.org/research/AgainstAnarchy.pdf}} Philosopher [[Chandran Kukathas]] said her "unremitting hostility towards the state and taxation sits inconsistently with a rejection of anarchism, and her attempts to resolve the difficulty are ill-thought out and unsystematic."{{harvnb|Kukathas|1998|p=55}} She acknowledged [[Aristotle]] as a great influence"About the Author" in {{harvnb|Rand|1992|p=1171}} and found early inspiration in [[Friedrich Nietzsche]],{{Harvnb|Sciabarra|1995|p=100–106}} although she rejected what she considered his anti-reason stance. Ronald E. Merrill and [[David Ramsay Steele]] point out a difference between her early and later views on the subject of sacrificing others.{{cite book |title=The Ideas of Ayn Rand |last=Merrill |first=Ronald E. |location=La Salle, Illinois |publisher=Open Court Publishing |year=1991 |isbn=0-8126-9157-1 |oclc=23254190 |pages=38–39}}{{cite journal |first=David Ramsay |last=Steele |authorlink=David Ramsay Steele |title=Alice in Wonderland |journal=[[Liberty (1987)|Liberty]] |url=http://libertyunbound.com/article.php?id=212 |year=1988 |month=May |volume=1 |issue=5 |pages=35–43}} Reprinted from ''Free Life: Journal of the Libertarian Alliance'' '''5''' (1). For example, the first edition of ''We the Living'' contained language which has been interpreted as advocating ruthless elitism: "What are your masses but mud to be ground underfoot, fuel to be burned for those who deserve it?" She remarked that in the [[history of philosophy]] she could only recommend "three A's"—Aristotle, [[Thomas Aquinas|Aquinas]], and Ayn Rand. Among the philosophers Rand held in particular disdain was [[Immanuel Kant]], whom she referred to as a "monster" and "the most evil man in history".{{cite journal |last=Rand |first=Ayn |title=Brief Summary |journal=[[The Objectivist]] |month=September |year=1971 |volume=10 |issue=9 |page=4}} Rand was strongly opposed to the view that reason is unable to know reality "as it is in itself", which she ascribed to Kant, and she considered her philosophy to be the "exact opposite" of Kant's on "every fundamental issue". Objectivist philosophers George Walsh{{cite journal |last=Walsh |first=George V. |title=Ayn Rand and the Metaphysics of Kant |journal=[[The Journal of Ayn Rand Studies]] |year=2000 |month=Fall |volume=2 |issue=1 |pages=69–103 |url=http://enlightenment.supersaturated.com/objectivity/walsh1/}} and Fred Seddon{{cite book |last=Seddon |first=Fred |title=Ayn Rand, Objectivists, and the History of Philosophy |publisher=University Press of America |location=Lanham, Maryland |year=2003 |pages=63–81 |isbn=0-7618-2308-5 |oclc=51969016}} both argue that Rand misinterpreted Kant. In particular, Walsh argues that both philosophers adhere to many of the same basic positions, and that Rand exaggerated her differences with Kant. Walsh says that for many critics, Rand's writing on Kant is "ignorant and unworthy of discussion". Rand scholars Douglas Den Uyl and Douglas Rasmussen, while stressing the importance and originality of her thought, describe her style as "literary, hyperbolic and emotional."{{cite journal |title=Nozick On the Randian Argument |last1=Den Uyl |first1=Douglas |last2=Rasmussen |first2=Douglas |journal=[[The Personalist]] |year=1978 |month=April |volume=59 |page=203 |lastauthoramp=y}} Similarly, philosopher Jack Wheeler says that despite "the incessant bombast and continuous venting of Randian rage," Rand's ethics is "a most immense achievement, the study of which is vastly more fruitful than any other in contemporary thought."Wheeler, Jack. "Rand and Aristotle" in {{harvnb|Den Uyl|Rasmussen|1986|p=96}} In 1976, she said that her most important contributions to philosophy were her "theory of concepts, [her] ethics, and [her] discovery in politics that evil—the violation of rights—consists of the initiation of force."{{harvnb|Rand|2005|p=166}} ==Contemporary reception== When they were first published, Rand's novels were derided by some critics as long and melodramatic.{{harvnb|Gladstein|1999|pp=117–119}} They became bestsellers largely due to word of mouth.{{harvnb|Paxton|1998|p=120}}; {{harvnb|Britting|2004|p=87}} The first reviews Rand received were for her play ''Night of January 16''. Reviews of the Broadway production were mixed, and Rand considered even the positive reviews to be embarrassing because of significant changes made to her script by the producer.{{harvnb|Branden|1986|pp=122–124}} Rand herself described her first novel, ''We the Living'', as not being widely reviewed, but Michael S. Berliner says "it was the most reviewed of any of her works," with approximately 125 different reviews being published in more than 200 publications. Overall these reviews were more positive than the reviews she received for her later work.{{cite book |last=Berliner |first=Michael S. |chapter=Reviews of ''We the Living'' |title=Essays on Ayn Rand's We the Living |editor-last=Mayhew |editor-first=Robert |editor-link=Robert Mayhew (philosopher) |location=Lanham, Maryland |publisher=Lexington Books |year=2004 |isbn=0-7391-0698-8 |oclc=52979186 |pages=147–151}} Her 1938 novella ''Anthem'' received little attention from reviewers, both for its first publication in England and for subsequent re-issues.{{cite book |last=Berliner |first=Michael S. |chapter=Reviews of ''Anthem'' |title=Essays on Ayn Rand's Anthem |editor-last=Mayhew |editor-first=Robert |editor-link=Robert Mayhew (philosopher) |location=Lanham, Maryland |publisher=Lexington Books |year=2005 |isbn=0-7391-1031-4 |oclc=57577415 |pages=55–60}} Rand's first bestseller, ''The Fountainhead'', received far fewer reviews than ''We the Living'', and reviewers' opinions were mixed.{{cite book |last=Berliner |first=Michael S. |chapter=''The Fountainhead'' Reviews |title=Essays on Ayn Rand's The Fountainhead |editor-last=Mayhew |editor-first=Robert |editor-link=Robert Mayhew (philosopher) |location=Lanham, Maryland |publisher=Lexington Books |year=2006 |isbn=0-7391-1578-2 |oclc=70707828 |pages=77–82}} There was a positive review in ''The New York Times'' that Rand greatly appreciated.{{harvnb|Rand|1995|p=74}} The ''Times'' reviewer called Rand "a writer of great power" who writes "brilliantly, beautifully and bitterly," and it stated that she had "written a hymn in praise of the individual... you will not be able to read this masterful book without thinking through some of the basic concepts of our time."{{cite news |first=Lorine |last=Pruette |work=The New York Times |date=May 16, 1943 |title=Battle Against Evil |page=BR7 |url=http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20610FD3D5C167B93C4A8178ED85F478485F9}} There were other positive reviews, but Rand dismissed most of them as either not understanding her message or as being from unimportant publications. Some negative reviews focused on the length of the novel, such as one that called it "a whale of a book" and another that said "anyone who is taken in by it deserves a stern lecture on paper-rationing." Other negative reviews called the characters unsympathetic and Rand's style "offensively pedestrian." Rand's 1957 novel ''Atlas Shrugged'' was widely reviewed, and many of the reviews were strongly negative.Berliner, Michael S. "The ''Atlas Shrugged'' Reviews" in {{harvnb|Mayhew|2009|pp=133–137}} In the ''[[National Review]]'', conservative author [[Whittaker Chambers]] called the book "sophomoric" and "remarkably silly". He described the tone of the book as "shrillness without reprieve" and accused Rand of supporting the same godless system as the [[Religion in the Soviet Union|Soviets]], claiming "From almost any page of ''Atlas Shrugged'', a voice can be heard, from painful necessity, commanding: 'To a gas chamber—go!{{' "}}{{cite journal |last=Chambers |first=Whittaker |authorlink=Whittaker Chambers |title=Big Sister is Watching You |journal=[[National Review]] |pages=594–596 |url=http://www.nationalreview.com/flashback/flashback200501050715.asp |date=December 8, 1957}} ''Atlas Shrugged'' received positive reviews from a few publications, but Rand scholar [[Mimi Reisel Gladstein]] later wrote that "reviewers seemed to vie with each other in a contest to devise the cleverest put-downs," calling it "execrable claptrap" and "a nightmare;" they said it was "written out of hate" and showed "remorseless hectoring and prolixity." Author [[Flannery O'Connor]] wrote in a letter to a friend that "The fiction of Ayn Rand is as low as you can get re fiction. I hope you picked it up off the floor of the subway and threw it in the nearest garbage pail. She makes [[Mickey Spillane]] look like Dostoevsky."{{cite book |last=O'Connor |first=Flannery |title=The Habit of Being: Letters of Flannery O'Connor |editor-first=Sally |editor-last=Fitzgerald |location=New York |publisher=Farrar, Straus, and Giroux |year=1979 |isbn=0-374-52104-2 |page=398}} Rand's nonfiction received far fewer reviews than her novels had. The tenor of the criticism for her first nonfiction book, ''[[For the New Intellectual]]'', was similar to that for ''Atlas Shrugged'',{{harvnb|Gladstein|1999|p=119}}{{harvnb|Burns|1999|pp=193–194}} with philosopher [[Sidney Hook]] likening her approach to "the way philosophy is written in the Soviet Union"{{cite news |first=Sidney |last=Hook |authorlink=Sidney Hook |title=Each Man for Himself |work=[[The New York Times Book Review]] |date=April 9, 1961 |page=28 |url=http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F70914F83B5B147A93CBA9178FD85F458685F9}} and author [[Gore Vidal]] calling her viewpoint "nearly perfect in its immorality".{{cite book |first=Gore |last=Vidal |authorlink=Gore Vidal |title=Rocking the Boat |chapter=Two Immoralists: Orville Prescott and Ayn Rand |publisher=Little, Brown |location=Boston |year=1962 |oclc=291123 |page=234}} Reprinted from ''[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]]'', July 1961. Her subsequent books got progressively less attention from reviewers. During Rand's lifetime her work received little attention from academic scholars. When ''With Charity Toward None: An Analysis of Ayn Rand's Philosophy'', the first academic book about Rand's philosophy, appeared in 1971, its author William F. O'Neill declared writing about Rand "a treacherous undertaking" that could lead to "guilt by association" for taking her seriously.{{cite book |title=With Charity Toward None: An Analysis of Ayn Rand's Philosophy |last=O'Neill |first=William F. |location=New York |publisher=Littlefield, Adams & Company |year=1977 |origyear=1971 |isbn=0-8226-0179-6 |oclc=133489 |page=3}} A few articles about Rand's ideas appeared in academic journals prior to her death in 1982, many of them in ''[[The Personalist]]''.{{harvnb|Gladstein|1999|p=115}} One of these was "On the Randian Argument" by [[Harvard University]] professor [[Robert Nozick]], who argued that her [[meta-ethical]] argument is unsound and fails to solve the [[is–ought problem]] posed by [[David Hume]].{{cite journal |title=On the Randian Argument |last=Nozick |first=Robert |authorlink=Robert Nozick |journal=[[The Personalist]] |year=1971 |month=Spring |volume=52 |pages=282–304}} Some responses to Nozick by other academic philosophers were also published in ''The Personalist''.These included{{cite journal |title=Nozick and Rand on Property Rights |last=Machan |first=Tibor |authorlink=Tibor R. Machan |journal=The Personalist |year=1977 |month=April |volume=58 |pages=192–195}} and{{cite journal |title=Nozick On the Randian Argument |last1=Den Uyl |first1=Douglas |last2=Rasmussen |first2=Douglas |journal=The Personalist |year=1978 |month=April |volume=59 |pages=184–205}} Academic consideration of Rand as a literary figure during her life was even more limited. Gladstein was unable to find any scholarly articles about Rand's novels when she began researching her in 1973, and only three such articles appeared during the rest of the 1970s.{{harvnb|Gladstein|2005|pp=57–58, 63}}. The articles identified by Gladstein are:{{cite journal |title=The Extroflective Hero: A Look at Ayn Rand |last=Gordon |first=Philip |journal=[[Journal of Popular Culture]] |year=1977 |month=Autumn |volume=10 |issue=4 |pages=701–710}};{{cite book |title=The Modern American Novel and the Movies |chapter=Ayn Rand in the Stockyard of the Spirit |last=McGann |first=Kevin |editor1-last=Peary |editor1-first=Gerald |editor1-link=Gerald Peary |editor2-last=Shatzkin |editor2-first=Roger (eds) |location=New York |publisher=Frederick Ungar Publishing |year=1978 |isbn=0-8044-2682-1 |oclc=4192104 |lastauthoramp=y}}; and her own article,{{cite journal |title=Ayn Rand and Feminism: An Unlikely Alliance |last=Gladstein |first=Mimi R. |journal=[[College English]] |year=1978 |month=February |volume=39 |issue=6 |pages=25–30}} On the 100th anniversary of Rand's birth in 2005, ''[[The New York Times]]'' referred to her fictional writing as quaint [[Utopian]] "retro fantasy" and programmatic [[neo-Romanticism]] of the misunderstood artist, while criticizing her characters "isolated rejection of democratic society."[http://www.nytimes.com/2005/02/02/books/02rand.html?_r=4&ex=1265086800&oref=slogin&pagewanted=print&position= Considering the Last Romantic, Ayn Rand, at 100] by Edward Rothstein, ''[[The New York Times]]'', February 2, 2005 Meanwhile, in 2009, [[GQ magazine]]'s critic columnist Tom Carson described her books as "capitalism's version of middlebrow religious novels" such as ''[[Ben-Hur: A Tale of the Christ|Ben-Hur]]'' and the ''[[Left Behind]]'' series. ==Legacy== [[Image:Ayn Rand quote, American Adventure, Epcot Center, Walt Disney World.jpg.jpg|thumb|right|alt=An engraving in all capital letters that reads: "Throughout the centuries there were men who took first steps down new roads armed with nothing but their own vision." Ayn Rand|A quote from Rand's book ''The Fountainhead'', on the wall directly across from the entrance to [[The American Adventure]] rotunda at [[Walt Disney World Resort|Walt Disney World's]] [[Epcot]]]] {{See also|Objectivist movement}} Rand's books continue to be widely sold and read, with 25 million copies sold as of 2007, and 800,000 more being sold each year according to the [[Ayn Rand Institute]].{{cite web|title=Sales of Ayn Rand Books Reach 25 million Copies |url=http://www.aynrand.org/site/News2?page=NewsArticle&id=17345 |date=April 7, 2008 |accessdate=April 5, 2010 |publisher=Ayn Rand Institute}} In addition, the Ayn Rand Institute provides 400,000 copies of Rand’s novels every year for free to [[Advanced Placement]] high school programs in the [[United States]]. She has also influenced notable people in different fields. Examples include philosophers [[John Hospers]], [[George H. Smith]], [[Allan Gotthelf]], [[Robert Mayhew (philosopher)|Robert Mayhew]] and [[Tara Smith (philosopher)|Tara Smith]], economists [[Alan Greenspan]], [[George Reisman]] and [[Murray Rothbard]], psychologist [[Edwin A. Locke]], historian [[Robert Hessen]], and political writer [[Charles Murray (author)|Charles Murray]]. ===Popular interest=== When a 1991 survey conducted for the [[Library of Congress]] and the [[Book-of-the-Month Club]] by the Information Analysis System Corporation asked what the most influential book in the respondent's life was, Rand's ''Atlas Shrugged'' was the second most popular choice, after the [[Bible]].{{cite news |url=http://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/20/books/book-notes-059091.html |title=Book Notes |last=Fein |first=Esther B. |date=November 20, 1991 |work=The New York Times |page=C26}} Readers polled in 1998 and 1999 by [[Modern Library]] placed four of her books on the 100 Best Novels list, with ''Atlas Shrugged'' taking the top position, while another, ''[[The Virtue of Selfishness]]'', topped the 100 Best Nonfiction list. Books by other authors about Rand and her philosophy also appeared on the nonfiction list.{{cite web |url=http://www.randomhouse.com/modernlibrary/100best.html |title=100 Best |publisher=[[Random House]] |accessdate=June 2, 2009 | location=New York}} The validity of such lists has been disputed.{{cite web |url=http://www.enotes.com/contemporary-literary-criticism/literature-millennial-lists |title=Literature and Millennial Lists |publisher=eNotes.com |accessdate=August 2, 2009}} Freestar Media/Zogby polls conducted in 2007 found that around eight percent of American adults have read ''Atlas Shrugged''.{{cite web |url=http://www.freestarmedia.com/randpoll2007.html |title=Atlas Shrugged by Ayn Rand Read by 8.1% |date=October 17, 2007 |publisher=Freestar Media |accessdate=June 2, 2009}} Although Rand's influence has been greatest in the United States, there has been international interest in her work.{{harvnb|Gladstein|2005|p=66–67}}{{cite book |last=Delbroy |first=Bibek |authorlink=Bibek Debroy |chapter=Ayn Rand — The Indian Connection |title=Ayn Rand at 100 |editor-last=Machan |editor-first=Tibor R |editor-link=Tibor R. Machan |location=New Delhi, India |publisher=Pragun Publications |year=2006 |isbn=81-89645-57-9 |oclc=76829742 |pages=2–4}}{{cite news |last=Cohen |first=David |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/education/2001/dec/07/internationaleducationnews.highereducation |title=A growing concern |work=The Guardian |date=December 7, 2001 |location=London}} Rand has been cited by numerous writers, artists and commentators as an influence on their lives and thought. Rand or characters based on her figure prominently in novels by such authors as [[William F. Buckley]], [[Mary Gaitskill]], [[Matt Ruff]], [[J. Neil Schulman]], and [[Kay Nolte Smith]].{{harvnb|Sciabarra|2004|p=3}} Other authors and artists, such as [[Steve Ditko]],{{harvnb|Sciabarra|2004|pp=8–11}} [[Terry Goodkind]],{{cite web |url=http://www.objectivistcenter.org/ct-1695-Goodkind.aspx |title=The Randian Fantasies of Terry Goodkind |first=William E. |last=Perry |publisher=The Atlas Society |date=May 17, 2006 |accessdate=August 27, 2009}} and [[Neil Peart]],{{cite journal |last=Sciabarra |first=Chris Matthew |authorlink=Chris Matthew Sciabarra |journal=[[The Journal of Ayn Rand Studies]] |title=Rand, Rush, and Rock |volume=4 |issue=1 |year=2002 |month=Fall |pages=161–185 |url=http://www.nyu.edu/projects/sciabarra/essays/rush.htm}} have also cited her as an influence. In the business world, [[Mark Cuban]], owner of the [[Dallas Mavericks]], and [[John P. Mackey]], CEO of [[Whole Foods Market|Whole Foods]], have said they consider Rand crucial to their success.[http://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/15/business/15atlas.html?_r=3&oref=slogin&pagewanted=print Ayn Rand’s Literature of Capitalism] by Harriet Rubin, ''[[The New York Times]]'', September 15, 2007 While other "avowed Rand fans" include ''[[Playboy magazine]]'' founder [[Hugh Hefner]], and [[Wikipedia]] co-founder [[Jimmy Wales]]. In Hollywood, a city dear to Rand herself, actors [[Angelina Jolie]], [[Brad Pitt]], [[Christina Ricci]], [[Rob Lowe]] and [[Eva Mendes]] have all spoke positively about her work.[http://www.thenation.com/print/article/garbage-and-gravitas Garbage and Gravitas] by Corey Robin, ''[[The Nation]]'', May 20, 2010 Additionally, [[Farrah Fawcett]], whom Rand hoped would play Dagny Taggart in a 1978 TV version of ''Atlas Shrugged'' on NBC, declared the author a "literary genius." Rand and her works have been referred to in a variety of media. References to her have appeared on television shows including animated sitcoms, live-action comedies, dramas, and game shows.{{harvnb|Sciabarra|2004|pp=4–5}} ''[[The Philosophical Lexicon]]'', a satirical web site maintained by philosophers [[Daniel Dennett]] and Asbjørn Steglich-Petersen, defines a 'rand' as: "An angry tirade occasioned by mistaking philosophical disagreement for a personal attack and/or evidence of unspeakable moral corruption."{{cite web |url=http://www.philosophicallexicon.com/#R |title=The Philosophical Lexicon: R |first1=Daniel |last1=Dennett |authorlink1=Daniel Dennett |first2=Asbjørn |last2=Steglich-Petersen |year=2008 |accessdate=August 2, 2009}} [[Anton LaVey]], founder of the [[Church of Satan]], quipped that [[LaVeyan Satanism]] was "Ayn Rand with trappings."''Contemporary Religious Satanism: A Critical Anthology'', by Jesper Aagaard Petersen, Ashgate Publishing, 2009, ISBN 0754652866, pp 2 Rand's image appears on a [[Postage stamps and postal history of the United States|U.S. postage stamp]] designed by artist [[Nick Gaetano]],{{cite web |url=http://www.objectivistcenter.org/events/others/others-ayn-rand-stamp.asp |title=Ayn Rand U.S. Postage Stamp Ceremony |publisher=The Objectivist Center |accessdate=June 2, 2009}} while the ''[[BioShock]]'' video game series includes elements inspired by Rand's ideas.{{cite news |title=BioShock 2 developer interview |author=Cowen, Nick |work=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] |date=January 13, 2010 |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/video-games/6980675/BioShock-2-developer-interview.html |accessdate=February 10, 2010}} Two movies have been made about Rand's life. A 1997 documentary film, ''[[Ayn Rand: A Sense of Life]]'', was nominated for the [[Academy Award]] for [[Academy Award for Documentary Feature|Best Documentary Feature]].{{cite web |url=http://movies.nytimes.com/movie/158804/Ayn-Rand-A-Sense-of-Life/awards |title=''Ayn Rand: A Sense of Life'' – Awards |work=The New York Times |accessdate=August 2, 2009}} ''[[The Passion of Ayn Rand (film)|The Passion of Ayn Rand]]'', an independent film about her life, was made in 1999, starring [[Helen Mirren]] as Rand and [[Peter Fonda]] as her husband. The film was based on the [[The Passion of Ayn Rand (book)|book of the same name]] by [[Barbara Branden]], and won several awards.{{cite news |last=Elber |first=Lynn |agency=[[Associated Press]] |title='Ally,' 'Practice' grab top honors at Emmy awards |work=[[Ventura County Star]] |page=A01 |date=September 13, 1999}}{{cite news |last=Tourtellotte |first=Bob |agency=[[Reuters]] |title=Family dramas top Golden Globe Awards |work=[[The Seattle Times]] |page=E1 |date=January 24, 2000}} Attempts have been made to produce a film adaptation of ''Atlas Shrugged'', but none have been successful.Britting, Jeff. "Bringing ''Atlas Shrugged'' to Film" in {{harvnb|Mayhew|2009|p=195}} Fans of Ayn Rand can also network and seek potential romance on the [[dating website]] ''The Atlasphere''.[http://www.theatlasphere.com/ ''The Atlasphere''] A dating / networking website - "connecting admirers of ''The Fountainhead'' and ''Atlas Shrugged''" ===Jabs in popular culture=== [[Nick Gillespie]], editor in chief of ''[[Reason Magazine]]'', has remarked that "Rand's is a tortured immortality, one in which she's as likely to be a punch line as a protagonist" ... with "jibes at Rand as cold and inhuman, running through the [[popular culture]]."NPR (audio): [http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4475441&sourceCode=RSS "Marking the Ayn Rand Centennial"] by Nick Gillespie, editor in chief of ''Reason Magazine'' In the ''[[Futurama]]'' episode "[[I Second That Emotion (Futurama)|I Second That Emotion]]" futuristic mutants find Rand's works flushed down the toilet,[http://www.twiztv.com/scripts/futurama/season2/futurama-205.htm Script for Futurama Episode 205: "I Second That Emotion", by Patric M. Verrone] in the ''[[South Park]]'' episode "[[Chicken Lover]]" [[Officer Barbrady]] decides to return back to illiteracy after reading "this piece of shit" ''[[Atlas Shrugged]]'',[http://www.southparkstudios.com/clips/150385/?tag=Ayn+Rand South Park Episode # 203: Chicken Lover - excerpt] originally aired on May 20, 1998 and in the 2009 episode of ''[[The Simpsons]]'' "[[Four Great Women and a Manicure]]" [[Lisa Simpson]] asks her mother if Ayn Rand's ''[[The Fountainhead]]'' is the "Bible of [[right-wing]] losers?."[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/05/11/maggie-speaks-the-littles_n_201595.html Maggie Speaks! The Littlest Simpson Says Her First Sentence While Acting Out "The Fountainhead"] by Alex Leo, ''The Huffington Post'', May 11, 2009 Outside the world of animation, a March 11, 2009, episode of ''[[The Colbert Report]]'', featured host [[Stephen Colbert (character)|Stephen Colbert]] giving his "The Word" segment on what he deems the "Rand Illusion". During the six minute skit he sarcastically applauds the growing popularity of Ayn Rand's work ''Atlas Shrugged'', while [[tongue-in-cheek]]ly stating that he wants to "go [[John Galt|Galt]]" and live on an island with the CEOs, hedge fund managers, House Republicans and TV pundits.[http://www.colbertnation.com/the-colbert-report-videos/221335/march-11-2009/the-word---rand-illusion Video: The Word - "Rand Illusion"] by ''[[The Colbert Report]]'', originally aired on March 11, 2009 In the [[spoof]] self-help book/memoir ''[[Asshole: How I Got Rich and Happy by Not Giving a Shit About You]]'', American writer [[Martin Kihn]] claims to have found inspiration in the philosopher Ayn Rand, whom he decrees "The asshole's philosopher", while pontificating that "any aspiring asshole could learn a lot from ''[[The Fountainhead]]'' or ''[[The Virtue of Selfishness]]''."[http://women.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/women/the_way_we_live/article3662842.ece No more Mr Nice Guy for Marty Kihn] by Kate Spicer, ''The Times'', April 6, 2008 In a similar theme, ''[[GQ magazine]]'' composed an October 2009 ''"The Bitch is Back"'' expose, on how Rand has the power to turn "bright young kid(s)" who can't "overcome the Randian infection", into "Ayn Rand Assholes (ARA)".[http://www.gq.com/entertainment/books/200911/ayn-rand-dick-books-fountainhead?printable=true The Bitch is Back] by Andrew Corsello, ''[[GQ magazine]]'', October 27, 2009 ===Political influence=== {{See also|Libertarianism and Objectivism}} [[Image:TDTP08.JPG|thumb|left|A protester at an April 2009 [[Tea Party protests|Tea Party rally]] carries a sign referring to [[John Galt]], the hero of Rand's novel ''[[Atlas Shrugged]]''|alt=In a large outdoor crowd, a man holds up a poster with the words "I am John Galt" in all capital letters]] Although she rejected the labels "conservative" and "libertarian", Rand has had continuing influence on [[right-wing politics]], especially libertarianism.{{harvnb|Burns|2009|p=4}}; {{harvnb|Gladstein|2009|pp=107–108, 124}} In a history of the [[libertarian movement]], journalist [[Brian Doherty (journalist)|Brian Doherty]] described her as "the most influential libertarian of the twentieth century to the public at large",{{harvnb|Doherty|2007|p=11}} and biographer Jennifer Burns referred to her as "the ultimate gateway drug to life on the right."{{harvnb|Burns|2009|p=4}} Burns further extrapolates on the gulf between Rand and conservatives, noting that "whereas traditional conservatism emphasized duties, responsibilities, and social interconnectedness, at the core of the right-wing ideology that Rand spearheaded was a rejection of moral obligation to others."{{harvnb|Burns|2009|pp=209}} Despite Rand's untraditionally-[[GOP]] stance as a [[pro-choice]] [[atheist]], the political figures who cite Rand as an influence are most often conservative or libertarian members of the United States [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]].{{harvnb|Doherty|2009|pp=54}} U.S. [[United States Congress|Congressmen]] [[Bob Barr]],{{harvnb|Gladstein|2009|p=124}} [[Ron Paul]],{{harvnb|Heller|2009|p=xi}} and [[Paul Ryan (politician)|Paul Ryan]]{{harvnb|Doherty|2009|p=51}} have acknowledged her influence on their lives, as has Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States [[Clarence Thomas]].{{cite book |last=Thomas |first=Clarence |authorlink=Clarence Thomas |title=[[My Grandfather's Son: A Memoir]] |location=New York |publisher=Harper Perennial |year=2007 |pages=62, 187 |isbn=0-06-056556-X |oclc=191930033}}; and ''60 Minutes'', "Interview with Clarence Thomas," September 30, 2007. Former U.S. President [[Ronald Reagan]] described himself as an "admirer" of Rand in private correspondence in the 1960s,{{cite book |last=Reagan |first=Ronald |authorlink=Ronald Reagan |editor1-first=Kiron K. |editor1-last=Skinner |editor2-first=Annelise |editor2-last=Anderson |editor3-first=Martin |editor3-last=Anderson |editor3-link=Martin Anderson (economist) |title=Reagan: A Life in Letters |year=2003 |location=New York |publisher=Free Press |pages=281–282 |isbn=0-7432-1966-X |oclc=52493559 |lastauthoramp=y}} and [[John Hospers]], the first presidential nominee of the U.S. [[Libertarian Party (United States)|Libertarian Party]], had a personal acquaintance with Rand in the early 1960s.{{harvnb|Burns|2009|pp=185–188}} Republican [[South Carolina]] Governor [[Mark Sanford]] wrote a 2009 review for ''[[Newsweek]]'' where he spoke of how he was "blown away" after first reading ''The Fountainhead'' and ''Atlas Shrugged'', while tying her signifigance to understanding the 2008 financial crisis.{{cite news |url=http://www.newsweek.com/2009/10/21/atlas-hugged.html |title=Atlas Hugged |first=Mark |last=Sanford |authorlink=Mark Sanford |work=[[Newsweek]] |date=October 22, 2009 |accessdate=June 23, 2010}} The [[financial crisis of 2007–2010]] spurred renewed interest in her works, especially ''Atlas Shrugged'', which some saw as foreshadowing the crisis.{{harvnb|Burns|2009|pp=283–284}}; {{harvnb|Doherty|2009|pp=51–52}}; {{harvnb|Gladstein|2009|p=125}} Conservative talk show hosts, such as [[Glenn Beck]],{{cite web |url=http://www.glennbeck.com/content/articles/article/198/22226/ |title=March to Socialism - Capitalism dead? |first=Glenn |last=Beck |authorlink=Glenn Beck |publisher=GlennBeck.com |date=March 3, 2009 |accessdate=April 10, 2010}} [[Neal Boortz]]{{cite web |url=http://boortz.com/nealz_nuze/2008/12/how-about-a-mini-atlas-shrugge.html |title=How About A Mini Atlas Shrugged? |first=Neal |last=Boortz |authorlink=Neal Boortz |publisher=Boortz.com |date=December 18, 2008 |accessdate=April 10, 2010}} and [[Rush Limbaugh]]{{cite web |first=Yaron |last=Brook |authorlink=Yaron Brook |title=Is Rand Relevant? |work=Wall Street Journal |date=March 14, 2009 |url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB123698976776126461.html |page=A7}} recommended the novel to their audiences, and opinion articles compared real-world events with the plot of the novel.{{harvnb|Gladstein|2009|p=125}}; {{harvnb|Doherty|2009|pp=54}} Signs mentioning Rand and her fictional hero [[John Galt]] appeared at [[Tea Party protests]],{{harvnb|Doherty|2009|pp=51–52}} while the [[Cato Institute]]'s [[Will Wilkinson]] quipped that "going Galt" had become the "libertarian-conservative's version of progressives threatening to move to Canada."{{cite journal |url=http://motherjones.com/print/24733 |title=And the Rand Played On |first=Amy |last=Benfer |work=[[Mother Jones]] |month=July/August |year=2009}} During this period there was also increased criticism of her ideas, especially from the [[political left]], with critics blaming her support of [[selfishness]] and [[free markets]] for the economic crisis, particularly through her influence on Alan Greenspan.{{harvnb|Burns|2009|p=283}} For example, the left-leaning ''[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]'' remarked that "Rand's particular genius has always been her ability to turn upside down traditional hierarchies and recast the wealthy, the talented, and the powerful as the oppressed", while ''[[The Nation]]'' alleged similarities between the "moral syntax of Randianism" and [[fascism]]. ===Academia=== Since Rand's death in 1982, interest in her work has gradually increased.{{harvnb|Gladstein|2009|pp=114–122}}{{cite book |editor-first=John R. |editor-last=Shook |first1=Gregory |last1=Salmieri |first2=Allan |last2=Gotthelf |author2-link=Allan Gotthelf |chapter=Rand, Ayn (1905–82) |title=The Dictionary of Modern American Philosophers |publisher=Thoemmes Continuum |location=London |year=2005 |isbn=1-84371-037-4 |oclc=53388453 |lastauthoramp=y |volume=4 |page=1995}}{{cite journal |last=McLemee |first=Scott |url=http://linguafranca.mirror.theinfo.org/9909/rand.html |title=The Heirs Of Ayn Rand: Has Objectivism Gone Subjective? |journal=[[Lingua Franca (magazine)|Lingua Franca]] |month=September |year=1999 |volume=9 |issue=6 |pages=45–55}} Historian Jennifer Burns has identified "three overlapping waves" of scholarly interest in Rand, the most recent of which is "an explosion of scholarship" in the 2000s.{{harvnb|Burns|2009|pp=295–296}} However, few universities currently include Rand or Objectivism as a philosophical specialty or research area, with many literature and philosophy departments dismissing her as a pop culture phenomenon rather than a subject for serious study.{{harvnb|Gladstein|2009|p=116}} Some academic philosophers have criticized Rand for what they consider her lack of rigor and limited understanding of philosophical subject matter. [[Chris Matthew Sciabarra]] has called into question the motives of some of Rand's critics because of what he calls the unusual hostility of their criticisms.{{harvnb|Sciabarra|1995|pp=9–14}} Sciabarra writes, "The left was infuriated by her anti-communist, pro-capitalist politics, whereas the right was disgusted with her atheism and civil libertarianism."{{harvnb|Sciabarra|1995|p=1}} Academics with an interest in Rand, such as Gladstein, Sciabarra, [[Allan Gotthelf]], [[Edwin A. Locke]], [[Robert Mayhew (philosopher)|Robert Mayhew]], and [[Tara Smith (philosopher)|Tara Smith]], have taught her work in academic institutions. Sciabarra co-edits the ''[[Journal of Ayn Rand Studies]]'', a nonpartisan peer-reviewed journal dedicated to the study of Rand's philosophical and literary work.{{cite journal |first=Chris Matthew |last=Sciabarra |authorlink=Chris Matthew Sciabarra |url=http://www.freeradical.co.nz/content/57/TheJournalofAynRandStudies.php |title=The Journal of Ayn Rand Studies: Four Years and Counting |journal=The Free Radical |issue=57 |month=July/August |year=2003 |pages=10–11}} In 1987 Gotthelf helped found the Ayn Rand Society, which is affiliated with the [[American Philosophical Association]] and has been active in sponsoring seminars about Rand and her ideas.{{cite web |url=http://www.aynrandsociety.org/ |title=Ayn Rand Society |accessdate=October 3, 2007}} Smith has written several academic books and papers on Rand's ideas, including ''Ayn Rand's Normative Ethics: The Virtuous Egoist'', a volume on Rand's ethical theory published by [[Cambridge University Press]]. Rand's ideas have also been made subjects of study at [[Clemson University|Clemson]] and [[Duke University|Duke]] universities.{{cite news |url=http://www.rutlandherald.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20050515/NEWS/505150346/1014 |title=Ayn Rand at 100: An 'ism' struts its stuff |first=Benjamin |last=Harvey |work=[[Rutland Herald]] |agency=Columbia News Service |date=May 15, 2005 |accessdate=June 4, 2009}} Scholars of English and American [[literature]] have largely ignored her work, although attention to her literary work has increased since the 1990s.{{harvnb|Gladstein|2005|p=59, 65–70}} In the ''[[Literary Encyclopedia]]'' entry for Rand written in 2001, John Lewis declared that "Rand wrote the most intellectually challenging fiction of her generation".{{cite web |last=Lewis |first=John David |authorlink=John Lewis (philosopher) |url=http://www.litencyc.com/php/speople.php?rec=true&UID=3705 |work=[[The Literary Encyclopedia]] |title=Ayn Rand |accessdate=August 2, 2009 |date=October 20, 2001}} In a 1999 interview in the ''[[Chronicle of Higher Education]],'' Rand scholar [[Chris Matthew Sciabarra]] commented, "I know they laugh at Rand," while forecasting a growth of interest in her work in the academic community.{{cite journal |last=Sharlet |first=Jeff |authorlink=Jeff Sharlet |work=[[The Chronicle of Higher Education]] |url=http://chronicle.com/article/Ayn-Rand-Has-Finally-Caught/20237/ |title=Ayn Rand Has Finally Caught the Attention of Scholars |date=April 9, 1999 |volume=45 |issue=31 |pages=A17–A18}} ===Institutes=== In 1985 Leonard Peikoff established the [[Ayn Rand Institute]], which "works to introduce young people to Ayn Rand's novels, to support scholarship and research based on her ideas, and to promote the principles of reason, rational self-interest, individual rights and laissez-faire capitalism to the widest possible audience."{{cite web |url=http://www.charitynavigator.org/index.cfm?bay=search.summary&orgid=8345 |title=Charity Navigator Rating - The Ayn Rand Institute |publisher=[[Charity Navigator]] |accessdate=June 2, 2009}} In 1990 [[David Kelley]] founded the Institute for Objectivist Studies,{{harvnb|Burns|2009|p=281}} now known as [[The Atlas Society]]. Its focus is on attracting readers of Rand's fiction; the associated Objectivist Center deals with more academic ventures.{{cite web |url=http://www.atlassociety.org/cth-11-1323-Our_Mission.aspx |title=Our Mission and Programs |publisher=[[The Atlas Society]] |accessdate=February 6, 2010}} In 2001 historian John McCaskey organized the Anthem Foundation for Objectivist Scholarship, which provides grants for scholarly work on Objectivism in academia.{{harvnb|Gladstein|2009|p=117}} The foundation has supported research at the [[University of Texas at Austin]],{{cite web |title=Anthem Foundation Renews Gift for Ayn Rand Research on 50th Anniversary of "Atlas Shrugged" |date=October 1, 2007 |publisher=University of Texas at Austin |url=http://www.utexas.edu/news/2007/10/01/lib_arts-2/ |accessdate=May 31, 2009}} the [[University of Pittsburgh]], [[Duke University]] and other schools.{{cite web |url=http://anthemfoundation.org/gifts-to-universities/fellowships.html |title=Fellowships & Other Multi-Year Gifts |publisher=Anthem Foundation |accessdate=February 6, 2010}} ==Notes== {{reflist|2}} [[Operator algebra]]s |author_abbrev_bot = |author_abbrev_zoo = |prizes = [[Fields Medal]] (1982)
[[Crafoord Prize]] (2001)
[[CNRS]] Gold Medal (2004) |footnotes = }} '''Alain Connes''' (born 1 April 1947) is a French [[mathematician]], currently Professor at the [[Collège de France]], [[IHÉS]] and [[Vanderbilt University]]. ==Work== Alain Connes is one of the leading specialists on [[operator algebra]]s. In his early work on [[von Neumann algebras]] in the 1970s, he succeeded in obtaining the almost complete classification of injective [[Von Neumann algebra#Factors|factor]]s. Following this he made contributions in [[K-theory|operator K-theory]] and [[index theory]], which culminated in the [[Baum-Connes conjecture]]. He also introduced [[cyclic homology|cyclic cohomology]] in the early 1980s as a first step in the study of [[noncommutative geometry|noncommutative differential geometry]]. Connes has applied his work in areas of [[mathematics]] and [[theoretical physics]], including [[number theory]], [[differential geometry]] and [[particle physics]]. ==Awards and honours== Connes was awarded the [[Fields Medal]] in 1982, the [[Crafoord Prize]] in 2001 and the gold medal of the [[CNRS]] in 2004. He is a member of the [[French Academy of Sciences]] and several foreign academies and societies, including the [[Royal Danish Academy of Sciences and Letters|Danish Academy of Sciences]], [[Norwegian Academy of Science and Letters|Norwegian Academy of Sciences]], [[Russian Academy of Sciences]], and [[United States National Academy of Sciences|US National Academy of Sciences]]. ==See also== * [[Cyclic homology]] * [[Factor (functional analysis)]] * [[Higgs boson]] * [[C*-algebra]] * [[M Theory]] * [[Groupoid]] *[[Criticism of non-standard analysis]] ==External links== *
